p: A careful examination of the 1H- and 13C-DEPT-135 NMR data in DMSO-d 6 clearly indicates the nature and extent of lithium incorporation into purpurin. 1H-NMR of the pristine purpurin showed multiplets at δ 7.8–8.1 ppm for the C-ring, a singlet at δ 6.58 ppm for the A-ring proton and singlets for the hydroxyl groups at δ 13.30, 13.05 and 11.57 ppm ( Figure 3a). The broad singlet at δ 11.57 ppm was assigned to the phenolic hydroxyl groups (H b), as it was broad due to weak intra-molecular H-bonding and chemical exchange. The 1H NMR of ELP-1 and of pristine purpurin, were found to be similar except for the phenolic hydroxyl groups (H a, H b and H c) and the aromatic proton (H d) in A-ring. Lithiation process in purpurin was identified by waning of phenolic hydroxyl groups (–OH a and –OH c), upfield shift of aromatic H d proton and downfield shift of –OH b signal ( Figure 3a–e). In case of 1:1 ratio of purpurin with LiOAc, –OH b shifted downfield to δ 16.58 ppm and the H d proton shifted upfield to δ 5.65 ppm. Upon increasing the purpurin-LiOAc concentration to 1:2 ratio, the –OH b signal shifted downfield at δ 18.12 ppm, whereas H d shifted upfield to δ 5.58 ppm ( Figures 3a, 3d, 3e). A similar trend was also observed in ELP-2, where –OH b proton shifted downfield to δ 18.19 ppm from δ 13.91 [ELP-1] and 11.58 ppm [pristine purpurin] ( Figures 3a, 3b, 3c). Likewise, the H d proton shifted upfield to δ 5.55 ppm from δ 6.35 and 6.58 ppm in ELP-1 and in pure purpurin, respectively. The extreme downfield shifts of the enolic –OH b group is attributed to the α,β-unsaturated carbonyl conjugation. The extent of downfield shift depends on the equilibrium between the mono- and di-lithiated species. When the di-lithiated species dominate, the –OH b resonance has a maximum downfield of δ 18.14 ppm, which was observed in ELP-2 and chemically lithiated purpurin (1:2 ratio).
